text: one thing is certain almost whoever you
vote for there will still be cuts after
the election and a lot of them in fact
we're not even halfway through the era
of austerity after five years of cuts to
some government departments of nearly 30
percent a two-year public sector pay
freeze and sixteen billion pounds worth
of cuts to benefits there is still a lot
more pain to come why well in parts
because ministers have chosen to protect
the NHS and pensions which together make
up a massive chunk of government
spending so who will cut what while the
Tories are planning a further 12 billion
pounds worth of welfare savings and an
extra 13 billion pounds squeeze on
government departments the Liberal
Democrats say they would cut benefits by
4 billion pounds put up taxes by 8
billion and also trimmed government
departments by 13 billion labour say
they'd impose cuts on unprotected
government departments every year and
curb some welfare payments such as child
benefit but these are just the broad
outlines unsurprisingly none of the main
parties want to spell out in detail
exactly what they would cut and how
deeply the true scale of the cuts to
come may have to wait until the first
budget after the election
